Award.AwardTitle: IRES in China - Advanced Materials for a Sustainable Development
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is a grant in response to Program Solicitation 04-036, International Research Experiences for Students (IRES). The research topic of this program is the development of advanced materials for applications in energy generation and storage and environmental remediation processes. The Clarkson University program will collaborate with Corning, Inc., in New York State, Corning Research China and host research mentors at Tsinghua University and the Chinese Academy of Science Institute of Physics in Beijing, China. Six to twelve undergraduates and three graduate students will travel to China in each of three summers, starting in 2011. Student recruitment will be national, and an effort will be made to include underrepresented minorities.

Because of challenges in energy production and management as well as environmental concerns, new processes of energy conversion and storage are needed, and such processes require advanced materials with tailored properties. Examples include the need to increase the efficiency of solar-energy systems. The students in this program will collaborate with leading materials researchers to explore methods for designing and fabricating materials with needed properties. This international experience will broaden the students? understanding of the world and prepare them to engage with Chinese and American colleagues in the future course of their careers. Clarkson plans to institutionalize research and education exchange programs based on this model. Expanding it through both industrial and academic partners will contribute to broader internationalization of U.S. institutions.

ProgramReference.Text: US CHINA COOP IN BASIC SCIENCE

POR.DRECONTENT:
Between 2011-13, this project provided 18 undergraduate students and 4 graduate students the opportunity to conduct nine weeks of summer research at leading institutions in China. The students made progress in advanced materials research focused on energy and environment issues. These issues have a direct impact on sustainable economic development. This in-depth experience allowed them to learn how these challenges are being tackled in China's fast growing economy.

The students came from: Indiana, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, Minnesota, Missouri, Montana, New York, Rhode Island, Texas, and Virginia. For many of them, this was their first experience outside of the US. The language barrier forced them to become efficient communicators. They learned to listen carefully to understand their Chinese colleagues' thoughts. They learned to organize their own thoughts first, then use the most accurate and understandable way to convey their thoughts to their colleagues. Students and hosts both had to deal with the frustrations of trying to communicate and overcome the barrier of limited vocabulary in the other’s language. They learned, under challenging circumstances, to appreciate the joy of true communication.

Many of these students will grow to become leaders in  society. The exposure they had to a different life style and value sets  was life-altering. Their experience helps to build a talent pool with a global perspective.

To get an overview of the students experience and impacts of the project, please see the website http://web2.clarkson.edu/projects/reushen/ires_china/.
